descriptions.content:
Possession and existence are constructed with the use of the verb བྱུང་ in the (perfective) past tense (in association with the various evidential moods: assertive, testimonial, egophoric).

  • མོ་རང་ལ་མཚེ་མ་བྱུང་པ་རེད། “She had twins.”
  • ཁོང་ལ་དངུལ་བྱུང་པ་རེད། “He got some money.”
  • རྙོག་ཁྲ་བྱུང་པ་རེད། “There were some problems.”
  • རྙོག་ཁྲ་བྱུང་སོང་། “He had problems.” (Or, “There were problems.”)
  • ངར་རྙོག་ཁྲ་བྱུང་། “I had problems.” (Egophoric)

When the complement of the subject is an adjective, the verb བྱུང་ in the (perfective) past is also used (in association with the various evidential moods: assertive, testimonial, egophoric).

  • ལས་སླ་པོ་བྱུང་པ་རེད། “It was easy.”
  • སྐྱིད་པོ་བྱུང་སོང་། “It was pleasant.” (Testimonial)
  • སྐྱིད་པོ་བྱུང་། “It was pleasant (for me).” (Egophoric)

To convey a locative meaning, the verb བསྡད་ “to stay,” or its honorific བཞུགས་ is used in the (perfective) past (in association with the various evidential moods: assertive, testimonial, egophoric).

  • ཁོང་ལྷ་སར་ལོ་གསུམ་བཞུགས་པ་རེད། “He has been in Lhasa for three years.” (Literally: “stayed in Lhasa”)
  • ང་ལྷ་སར་ལོ་གསུམ་བསྡད་པ་ཡིན། “I have been in Lhasa for three years.” (Literally: “stayed in Lhasa”)

Note: In the case of the imperfective past, the same form as the present is used:

  • དེ་དུས་ཁོང་ལྷ་སར་ཡོད་རེད། “At that time he was in Lhasa.” (Literally: “is in Lhasa”)
